title: 114_hr3510
content: The Act is titled the "Department of Homeland Security Cybersecurity Strategy Act of 2015" and introduces a new section on cybersecurity strategy for the Department of Homeland Security. The Secretary must develop a departmental strategy for cybersecurity responsibilities within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The strategy should include strategic goals, operational priorities, and information on programs and policies necessary for executing cybersecurity responsibilities, including those related to the national cybersecurity and communications integration center. The Secretary must develop a cybersecurity strategy within 60 days, including goals, priorities, programs, and policies. Considerations include existing cybersecurity strategies and plans. The Secretary must develop a cybersecurity strategy within 60 days, including goals, priorities, programs, and policies. The strategy should include roles and responsibilities of Department components and offices. Within 90 days, an implementation plan with strategic objectives, timelines, costs, and metrics must be issued. The strategy must be submitted to Congressional committees for assessment. The strategy required under subsection (a) must be submitted within 60 days, along with an implementation plan within 90 days. The strategy should include roles and responsibilities, while the implementation plan should detail legislative and budgetary proposals. The strategy must be unclassified but may contain a classified annex. The Department is not permitted to engage in monitoring or surveillance for tracking personally identifiable information. The Homeland Security Enterprise includes governmental and nongovernmental entities involved in homeland security. The Secretary of Homeland Security is prohibited from changing the location or reporting structure of the National Protection and Programs Directorate. The Secretary of Homeland Security is restricted from altering the location or reporting structure of any office or component within the Directorate without prior authorization from Congress. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The House of Representatives passed an amendment to the definition of 'incident' in the national cybersecurity and communications integration center, as part of the Homeland Security Act of 2002.
